title: Hurricane Dorian to bring dangerous storm surge: What you need to know
text:
Hurricane Dorian to bring dangerous storm surge: What you need to know originally appeared on abcnews.go.com

Storm surge poses the biggest threat to people and property as powerful Hurricane Dorian targets Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas.

A storm surge watch has been issued along the Georgia coast where levels could reach 4 to 7 feet by Tuesday night into Wednesday morning.

PHOTO: In this file photo, a car sits abandoned in storm surge along North Fort Lauderdale Beach Boulevard as Hurricane Irma hits the southern part of the state, Sept. 10, 2017, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images, FILE) More

During Hurricane Katrina in 2005, at least 1,500 people died "directly, or indirectly, as a result of storm surge," the National Hurricane Center said.

But what is storm surge?

PHOTO: In this file photo, storm surge hits a small tree as winds from Hurricane Sandy reach Seaside Park in Bridgeport, Conn., Oct. 29, 2012. (Jessica Hill/AP, FILE) More

(MORE: As Hurricane Dorian approaches US, tips to keep in mind if you're evacuating)

Here's how it works:

As pressure falls in the hurricane's center, water levels rise. The water accumulates while the storm is still over the open ocean.

When the hurricane closes in on land, its strong winds push that water toward the coast and up onto land, creating walls of water sometimes as high as 20 feet.

(MORE: What to know about hurricane categories and the Saffir-Simpson wind scale)

PHOTO: In this file photo, a 3-story condominium has collapsed after Hurricane Irma send a storm surge and eroded the building foundations, in Islamorada, Florida Keys, Sept. 12, 2017. (Marcus Yam/Los Angeles Times via Getty Images, FILE) More

The danger to people inside houses on the coast is the deluge of water that can flood homes and overpower walls rapidly.

When Hurricane Sandy hit New York and New Jersey in 2012, many homes filled quickly with water that reached levels of 8 to 9 feet.

The risks can be even greater if storm surge combines with high tide, creating a devastating, rapid rise in water levels.
